subject: Ethics
title: Cultural Gift-Giving Ethics
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Cultural Gift-Giving Ethics.

hook.text: In Japan, refusing a gift is deeply rude. In some Western offices, accepting one is a bribe. Who's right?

buildup.text: Gift-giving ethics vary wildly across cultures. What one society calls respect, another calls corruption.

discovery.text: The Foreign Corrupt Practices Act can punish Americans for cultural gift-giving normal in other countries.

twist.text: But cultural relativism has limits. When a 'gift' is worth $50,000, calling it tradition is a stretch.

climax.text: The ethics depend on intent, value, and context‚Äînot on any single culture's rules.

punchline.text: One culture's courtesy is another's crime. Context is everything.

quiz.question: Why can cultural gift-giving create ethical conflicts in international business?
options: All gift-giving is considered bribery under international trade law
What one culture sees as respectful custom, another may see as corruption or bribery
Gift-giving is only ethical when the gifts are under $10 in value
